Adsorption of methanol Daniel Bianchi, T. Chafik, Mohamed Khalfallah, Stanislas Jean Teichner * Universit~ Claude Bernard (Lyon 1), Laboratoire d'Application de la Chimie ~ l'Environnement, 69622 Villeurbanne Cddex, France Received 13 June 1994; revised 29 October 1994; accepted 31 October 1994 Abstract Less methanol is being adsorbed at 25, and decomposed during temperature-programmeddesorp- tion (TPD) on copper-containing catalysts CuO/ZrO2 and CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 than on the copperless catalysts ZrO2 and ZnO/ZrO2. On this last class of solids the concentration of hydroxyl groups decreases by adsorption of methanol whereas the reverse is observed on copper-containing catalysts, where also lower temperatures are required for the transformation of the methoxy groups into more oxidized species such as formate and carbonates. The influence of copper on these processes is explained by the spillover of hydrogen, through copper ions, from the methoxy groups to oxygen ions of zirconia. Keywords." Aerogel catalysts; Hydrogen spillover; Methanol adsorption; Methanol decomposition; Spillover 1. Introduction In the previous publications of this series [ 1-4] the controversy concerning the nature of the pivotal species in the synthesis of methanol from the reactants H2, CO, CO2 was largely discussed. It is generally assumed that either a formate or a carbonate type species is this pivotal intermediate. The controversy also concerns the nature of the reactant carbon monoxide or/and carbon dioxide which leads to this species. The support of zirconia is by itself a catalyst for the synthesis of methanol in contrast to silica or alumina supports [5 ] and, in addition, it provides * Corresponding author. Tel. (+33) 72448150, fax. (+33) 78941995. 0926-860X/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSDl O926-860X ( 94 )O0242-8 90 D. Bianchi et al./ Applied Catalysis A: General 123 ( 19951 89 110 adsorption sites for the surface reaction intermediates [6]. The first property of zirconia was explained [ 1 ] by its capacity to store hydrogen. The second property implicitly assumes that any intermediate species formed on one of the constituents of the catalyst (such as the formate species which may be formed on copper or on zinc) can be transferred onto some other constituent [5] and that this generalized aspect of spillover may become a part of the mechanism of the methanol synthesis. Indeed, if such a species can be hydrogenated into methoxy species at temperatures lower than its decomposition temperature into CO, CO2, H2 and H~O [7] the ease of the transfer of this species to the hydrogenating centres, possibly with the help of the support, may determine the activity of the catalyst. If the energetics of the formation of the species does not change much for the various sites involved, the driving force for its transfer would be the surface concentration gradient [8]. The hydrogen spillover from ZnO and/or CuO onto zirconia and the carbon monoxide spillover from CuO onto zirconia was envisaged previously [ 1,3 ]. In the chain of the intermediates the methoxy species is the final one. The investigation of its stability, surface concentration and of its eventual transfer onto various constituents of the catalyst may provide, by this sort of a reverse path, the clue to its origin and to the nature of the pivotal species. To obtain the methoxy species on the catalyst surface the interaction with methanol is the simplest method. This interaction with oxides such as ZnO, TiO2, ZrO2 [9-13], MgO [ 14], A1203, SiO2, CuO/ZnO and CuO/ZnO/AIRO3 [7,15-17] was studied to a rather limited extend. The formation of species such as formate, oxymethylene and various types of carbonates was also detected during this interaction [ 15,16,18]. The TPD experi- ments of adsorbed methanol showed its decomposition into CO, CO2, H2, CH4, HCOOH, HCHO and dimethyl ether (DME) [9-11,17]. Studying the nature of the species formed by the interaction with methanol of the various catalyst com- ponents and tracking the desorption products may therefore help in defining steps that lead from the adsorption of reactants (CO, CO2, H2) to the formation of the reaction product (CH3OH) or at least of some essential intermediate. To be com- plete this study also involves, in the forthcoming paper, that of the interaction with hydrogen of various adsorbed species. 2. Experimental Isothermal adsorption of reactants and reaction products, followed by tempera- ture-programmed desorption (TPD) or reaction (TPR), termed transient methods, were described previously [ 1-4] together with IR spectroscopy. In the present case the adsorbate is liquid methanol which is introduced into a saturating device and its vapour is carried out by a stream of helium. The vapour pressure of methanol used in this work is selected in the interval 37.5 Torr (5) to 135 Torr (25) ( 1 Torr = 133.3 Pa). In this series of papers four aerogel catalysts are investigated, all supported by zirconia aerogel which, by itself, also catalyses methanol synthesis D. Bianchi et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 123 (1995) 89-110 91 [18,19]. They are: ZrO2, ZnO (5%)/ZrO~, CuO (5%)/Zr02 and the ternary aerogel CuO (5%)/ZnO (5%)/ZRO2. Their preparation and properties were described previously [ 1,2] as well as their pretreatment, first in oxygen and then in helium at 400 (standardization), required to remove various organic impurities from the surface. Their interaction with methanol gives results which are sufficiently different for each catalyst to deserve a separate description. It is also easier, in this way, to distinguish the contribution of ZnO and/or CuO to ZrO2 in the mechanism of the interaction of the catalyst with methanol. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. This decomposition does not proceed from the adsorbed methanol because in the TPD experiment of pread- sorbed methanol the first release of gases (CH4, DME and HCOOH) was registered above 390 (Fig. 2). In the TPR experiment under methanol the reaction which starts at 300 may proceed through the Rideal-Eley mechanism, involving adsorbed species (formed from methanol) and gaseous methanol. In the TPD experiment of preadsorbed methanol the compounds desorbed may be formed directly through interaction of adsorbed methanol with the surface of the solid or they may result from surface reactions of species formed from adsorbed methanol. Their desorption may be coincident to their formation or it may be delayed with respect to the rise of the temperature in the TPD. The infrared analysis brings a remarkable help in this investigation. Study by Fourier transform infrared (FT-1R) spectroscopy The adsorption of methanol ( 135 Torr in helium flow) at 25 on a standardized zirconia results in the disappearance of the initial hydroxyl groups at 3770 cm ~, described in ref. [ I ], whereas the second band of the hydroxyl groups at 3680 cm I is barely affected. This is in agreement with the isothermal formation of water (Fig. 1 ) and that detected by TPD (Fig. 2) after adsorption of methanol. This adsorption consumes therefore the hydroxyl groups, releasing water even at low temperatures (25) and it does not correspond to the dehydration of the surface but to the reaction: CH3OH(g) + M-OH --* M-OCH3- -+-H20(ad .... d g) 3770 cm ' 1635 cm ' The absence of the restoration of the hydroxyl bands by generated water was discussed previously [ 1 ]. For copperless aerogels a second decomposition process of adsorbed methanol was observed at higher temperatures. The IR study of the adsorbed species gives information on these differences. Methanol is adsorbed at 25 on two copper-containing solids essen- tially in the form of methoxy groups. Small amounts of the formate species and of the unidentate carbonate species are much more apparent than on copperless cata- lysts. The methoxy groups vanish during the TPD process around 200 whereas on copperless catalysts they are stable up to 350. This transformation of the methoxy groups, already at 200, on copper-containing catalysts generates new quantities of the formate and unidentate carbonate species and also new species such as carboxylate and ionic carbonate. The behaviour of the hydroxyl groups during the adsorption of methanol is also different on both series of solids. On copperless catalysts the intensity of the band at 3770 cm - 1 of these groups decreases very much after adsorption of methanol at 25, whereas both bands, at 3770 and 3680 cm- 1, decrease considerably at 250. On copper-containing catalysts the intensity of the bands of the hydroxyl groups remains almost constant under these conditions. Moreover, a large but definite band at 3400 cm ~ accounts for the interaction between the hydroxyl groups but the band of the adsorbed water, at 1635 cm- ~, is not formed. Hence the mechanisms which control the adsorption and the decomposition of methanol are different on both series of solids. Besides, 110/xmol/g of carbon dioxide evolved (Table 1) represent 220/xatom/g of oxygen and 8/xmol/g of carbon monoxide correspond to 8 k~atom/ g of oxygen. The total figure for oxygen evolved in TPD is therefore 275 + 220 + 8 = 503 /zatom/g. For the catalyst CuO/ZrO> methanol contributes for only 140 /xatom/g of oxygen (see above). The missing amount of oxygen (503 - 140 = 363/xatom/g) can only come from copper oxide (5% in the catalyst) which is initially present in an amount of 610/xmol/g. The oxygen eliminated as water and carbon oxides corresponds then to the reduction of 59% of the CuO. The same type of calculation for the ternary catalyst CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 results in the reduction of 58% of CuO. If ZnO is reduced to some extent this proportion would be lower. The progressive oxidation of the methoxy groups on copper-containing catalysts involves thus the absence of the consumption of the hydroxyl groups (which at high temperatures are finally eliminated as water) and the intermediate formation of species like formate and then unidentate carbonate, in the schemes developed above. In contrast to the case for copperless catalysts, hydrogen is not released but remains stored in the form of OH's. These hydroxyl groups [ l ] account for the transformation of the methoxy groups (by loss of hydrogen) into the formate and carbonate species at temperatures much lower than for copperless catalysts [Eqs. (4) and (5)]. The final argument in favour of the spillover of hydrogen on copper-containing solids may be found in the absence of the formation of methane during the TPD experiments on these catalysts, in contrast to the formation of methane on both copperless catalysts (see above). Methane can be formed by the reduction of the methoxy groups localized on zirconia for all classes of catalysts (see above). If, on the contrary, these groups can lose hydrogen by the (reverse) spillover [8] through copper ions, this hydrogen being stored as OH's, they are easily transformed into formate and finally carbonate species and methane cannot be evolved instead. The extensive coverage of ZrO2 by CuO in both copper-containing catalysts [ 3] is in favour of this spillover phenomenon. In the reverse process, i.e. that of the synthesis of methanol from the reactants (CO, CO2, H2), it is not surprising that, assuming the forward spillover [ 1,2] of hydrogen and of carbon monoxide from copper onto zirconia, the catalysts con- 110 D. Methanol formed is more easily desorbed from the ternary catalyst (Table 1) whereas the decomposition process requires higher temperatures for copperless catalysts (Table 1). In contrast, lower temperatures are required for the transformation of the methoxy groups into formate and carbon- ate species on copper-containing catalysts (Table 1 ). The reversal of this process in the presence of hydrogen (conditions for synthesis) would also explain higher activity of catalysts in the presence of copper. coredata.dc:description: Less methanol is being adsorbed at 25Â°C, and decomposed during temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) on copper-containing catalysts CuO/ZrO2 and CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 than on the copperless catalysts ZrO2 and ZnO/ZrO2. On this last class of solids the concentration of hydroxyl groups decreases by adsorption of methanol whereas the reverse is observed on copper-containing catalysts, where also lower temperatures are required for the transformation of the methoxy groups into more oxidized species such as formate and carbonates. The influence of copper on these processes is explained by the spillover of hydrogen, through copper ions, from the methoxy groups to oxygen ions of zirconia.
